awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-FA Track B: Inclusive Insurance: Improving the Post-Flood Financial Resiliency of Low- and Moderate-Income Households
awd_abstract_narration:
Flooding is the costliest natural disaster and climate change is projected to escalate flood risk in many places. Prior research has found that low- and moderate-income (LMI) households suffer disproportionately and recover less quickly than more privileged residents. Financial resilience—the ability to recover from an economic shock—underpins other aspects of recovery and is a necessary condition for broader disaster resilience. Despite this, it is an under-researched aspect of climate adaptation and investigation of actionable solutions is scarce. The proposed project will fill this gap.

The project’s overarching goal is to increase the financial resilience of LMI households in New York City to escalating flood risk through the use of inclusive insurance. Inclusive insurance refers to any program that makes coverage available to those previously locked out of the insurance market. Our project will establish NYC as one of the first communities in the U.S. to harness these approaches. This project is a joint effort between the Wharton Risk Center at the University of Pennsylvania, the New York City Mayor’s Office of Resiliency, and the Center for New York City Neighborhoods (CNYCN). It also involves a research partnership with the Urban Institute, research and development work with Global Parametrics, technical assistance from Guy Carpenter, and support from the NYC Office of Management and Budget. 
The project has four interrelated objectives:  
1. Developing and deploying innovative, inclusive insurance pilots. The key pilot will be the purchase, by CNYCN, of a parametric flood insurance policy designed to rapidly provide emergency cash grants to LMI households post-flood. In addition, R&D will be undertaken on parametric flood policies that community development finance institutions can provide to protect LMI borrowers.
2.	Creating a community of practice that harnesses risk transfer for social recovery goals. This community will be developed through a workshop and new information sharing platforms. 
3.	Increasing the literacy and capacity of all partners. This includes training housing advisors on flood risk and insurance, providing pre-disaster consultations to fifty NYC households on risk reduction and insurance, and expanding the information available on FloodHelpNY.org, the local flood risk awareness platform.
4.	Linking research to actionable change. Three research projects will be undertaken, including a survey to quantify the length of delays in various sources of disaster recovery and the costs from these delays; a replicability and generalizability analysis of the project’s pilots; and a typology of the community-level benefits of widespread insurance purchase

The CIVIC Innovation Challenge is a joint program with Department of Energy Vehicle Technology Office, Department of Homeland Security Science and Technology Directorate, Federal Emergency Management Agency, and the NSF

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate-related extreme events are worsening around the globe. These disasters can impose a substantial financial burden and research has shown that low- and moderate-income (LMI) residents are disproportionately impacted. Accessing funds immediately is important for a range of potential impacts, including paying for evacuation or temporary lodging, removing water-damaged materials and clearing debris, higher commuting costs when transit is down, generators or fuel when power is lost, fixing needed appliances, or dealing with lost income when business is interrupted. Our research documented that when households do not have access to the needed financial resources, they can be forced to adopt costly strategies. This could include failing to pay bills, forgoing important expenses, selling possessions, or taking on additional work. Most sources of assistance after a disaster, such as federal aid, traditional insurance payouts, or loans, can take months or even years to make their way to those in need, leaving households struggling in the immediate aftermath of such events. A lack of resources for household recovery can have spillover impacts on local businesses and community recovery, as well.

The goal of this project was to increase the financial resilience of LMI households in New York City to escalating flood risk, particularly from increasing extreme-rainfall events, through inclusive insurance. Inclusive insurance is defined as any program or policy that makes insurance coverage available to those previously locked out of the insurance market. To achieve this broad goal, the project had four interrelated components: (1) developing an innovative, inclusive insurance pilot; (2) creating a community of practice that harnesses risk transfer for social recovery goals; (3) increasing the insurance literacy of all partners; and (4) linking research to actionable change.

The pilot we launched makes use of a new approach sometimes referred to as meso-insurance, group insurance, or community insurance, in which an intermediary helps to secure insurance coverage on behalf of a group. In our pilot program, the Center for NYC Neighborhoods (the Center) purchased a parametric risk transfer product designed to provide a fast payment to the Center in the event of an extreme rainfall-driven flood. If the policy is triggered, the Center would use the funds to activate an emergency grant program for LMI households suffering financial hardship from the flood (see figures). The pilot program, the Flood Recovery Fund, is designed to provide faster and more flexible funding than is currently available. The hypothesis is that the delivery of such grants quickly following a disaster could help prevent households from falling into greater financial precarity immediately after the flood.

In addition, the team completed research, scoping, and design work for a second insurance model to support microenterprises in vulnerable communities. Small businesses can be essential for disaster recovery, providing needed goods and services and reestablishing employment, and yet are themselves highly vulnerable to economic shocks. The proposed model links a parametric flood insurance product to loans disbursed by Community Development Finance Institutions (CDFIs) or, in a slightly different structure, would provide post-disaster financial liquidity to the CDFI itself. CDFIs are mission-driven organizations that provide low-interest financial services and technical support to a range of clients to create economic opportunity.

Our second activity with this grant was to create a community of practice of those working to harness risk transfer for social recovery goals. Communities of practice unite individuals and organizations with diverse perspectives who are engaged in efforts toward a shared goal or purpose. We made substantial progress on this through our culminating workshop, which brought together experts from the public and private sector, as well as researchers. The day consisted of targeted panels, group discussion, and time for networking. Post-workshop, the team heard that many new connections were made and several partnerships launched based on this event.

Risk transfer markets tend to be opaque to users. A third objective of this project was to increase understanding of disaster risk transfer markets and how they can be used to meet social recovery goals among all partners. Throughout the project, the team provided briefings and shared materials with other municipal staff, including in other local agencies, and with stakeholders of the Center, including their board and network housing advisors.

Finally, the project included several research projects to support further policy development around innovative insurance. The research team undertook a survey of disaster survivors, documenting their full financial trajectory. We found that insured households are less likely to experience high financial burdens in both the short- and longer-run post-disaster and are less likely to have unmet funding needs. The research team also created a typology of the community benefits of insurance by investigating the role of widespread take-up of insurance on community recovery, finding positive spillovers for the local economy through increased visitation to local businesses. Finally, the team produced two reports with lessons learned for replication.
